normalised: So, someone asked about units when buying veggies and groceries in India. It's a mix, really. You gotta know what's what to not get confused, especially if you're new here or ordering online.

unnormalised: Generally, for vegetables, you'll hear "kg" (kilogram) used a lot. Like, "1 kg potatoes" or "500 gms (grams) of tomatoes". Sometimes vendors use "paav" which is 250g. Keep in mind, 1 kg = 1000 gms. Fruits also mostly use "kg", but sometimes you'll see them sold by the "dozen", especially bananas. A dozen means 12.
normalised: Generally, for vegetables, you'll hear "kilogram" used a lot. Like, "one kilogram potatoes" or "five hundred grams of tomatoes". Sometimes vendors use "paav" which is two hundred and fifty grams. Keep in mind, one kilogram equals one thousand grams. Fruits also mostly use "kilogram", but sometimes you'll see them sold by the "dozen", especially bananas. A dozen means twelve.

unnormalised: For things like rice, wheat, and lentils, "kg" is standard. "5kg rice" or "10 kg atta" (wheat flour). For smaller quantities of spices, you'll see "gms" or maybe even "tbsp" (tablespoons) or "tsp" (teaspoons), especially in online recipes or when buying smaller packets. A rough conversion: 1 tbsp is around 15 ml (milliliters), and 1 tsp is about 5 ml.
normalised: For things like rice, wheat, and lentils, "kilogram" is standard. "five kilogram rice" or "ten kilogram atta" (wheat flour). For smaller quantities of spices, you'll see "grams" or maybe even "tablespoons" or "teaspoons", especially in online recipes or when buying smaller packets. A rough conversion: one tablespoon is around fifteen milliliters, and one teaspoon is about five milliliters.

unnormalised: Milk is sold in "liters" (L) or "ml" (milliliters). Paneer (cottage cheese) is usually sold in "gms" or "kg". Oil is almost always in liters, like "1L sunflower oil". Try to keep these in mind to avoid getting confused and paying extra for something you didn't intend to purchase.
normalised: Milk is sold in "liters" or "milliliters". Paneer (cottage cheese) is usually sold in "grams" or "kilograms". Oil is almost always in liters, like "one liter sunflower oil". Try to keep these in mind to avoid getting confused and paying extra for something you didn't intend to purchase.

unnormalised: Prices are usually listed per unit, so always check if the price is for 1 kg or 500 gms before you commit to buy. Also, bargaining is common in local markets, so knowing the standard units and approximate prices can help you get a good deal. It's just knowing the context that really helps with all these different units of measurement.
